0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-wealth-idUSKCN11Y27S	Forbes pegs Trump's wealth at $3.7 billion
column2: $800 million less than last year	"

column1: WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's estimated net worth is $3.7 billion
column2: $800 million less than a year ago
column3: Forbes magazine reported on Wednesday
column4: attributing the loss largely to New York's softening real estate market. The magazine probed 28 assets or asset classes owned by the New York businessman and found 18 had declined in value
column5: including Trump Tower in Manhattan and his Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach
column6: Florida. The value of his 40 Wall Street property in downtown New York had also declined
column8: which said it has been tracking Trump's wealth for 34 years. At the same time
column9: one asset remained steady while seven others - including 555 California Street
column10: the second tallest building in San Francisco - saw their value increase
column11: it reported. Representatives for the Trump campaign could not be immediately reached for comment.

column1: The report comes as Trump
column2: known as a reality television star as well as for his real estate business
column3: heads into the final stretch of campaigning for the Nov. 8 election.Trump
column4: seeking elected office for the first time
column5: has touted his business acumen in pressing for change in Washington. He has vowed to rip up trade deals
column6: negotiate with allies to make them pay more for their U.S. defense protection
column7: and have Mexico pay for a wall he has proposed along the southern U.S. border. If elected
column8: he would be the first billionaire to serve as president
column9: according to Forbes. Details of Trump's wealth are not publicly known because
column10: bucking a decades-old tradition of U.S. presidential candidates
column11: he has refused to release his tax returns. His Democratic rival
column12: former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
column13: earned $10.75 million in 2015 alongside her husband

column1: Clinton and others
column2: including some prominent Republicans
column3: have pressed Trump to release his returns. They have also raised questions about his net worth as well as his charitable contributions and business ties. Forbes said its analysis did not place any value on Trump's brand. It also disputed Trump's assertion in Monday night's  presidential debate that he reported $694 million in income from last year to the Federal Election Commission. Forbes said Trump mixed revenue and income in the document.

column1: Trump has so far given $54 million to his presidential campaign. His campaign has also paid his companies for office space in Trump Tower and use of his private airline
column2: among other expenses
column3: federal election filings have shown. Politico reported separately on Wednesday that Trump is considering giving more money to his campaign to fund an advertising blitz
column4: citing three sources close to him.Amid the campaign
column5: Trump made just one real estate deal in the past year: purchasing a Charleston
column8: Forbes said. (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson and Grant Smith; Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by Frances Kerry)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sept11-saudi-obama-idUSKCN11Y318	Obama says 9/11 legislation sets 'dangerous precedent': CNN	"
FORT LEE
column2: Va. President Barack Obama on Wednesday called the Senate's vote to override his veto of legislation allowing relatives of the victims of the Sept. 11
column4: attacks to sue Saudi Arabia's government a mistake.""If we eliminate this notion of sovereign immunity
column5: then our men and women in uniform around the world could potentially start seeing ourselves subject to reciprocal loss
column6: Obama said during a town hall meeting-style interview on CNN

column1: It's a dangerous precedent
column2: he said.

column1: (Reporting by Roberta Rampton

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-california-rape-cosby-idUSKCN11Y31P	California
column2: eyeing Cosby
column3: ends statute of limitations for rape	"

column1: By Sharon Bernstein
| SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif.

column1: SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. California Governor Jerry Brown on Wednesday signed a bill to end the statute of limitations for rape
column3: a measure inspired by accusations against comedian Bill Cosby
column4: some of which surfaced decades after alleged crimes occurred.Cosby
column5: who built a long career on family friendly comedy
column6: including his long-running NBC sitcom ""The Cosby Show
column7: has steadfastly denied ever assaulting anyone and has insisted that all his sexual encounters were consensual.He is charged in Pennsylvania with drugging and sexually assaulting a former Temple University employee
column9: at his home in 2004. In California
column10: he faces a civil suit by a woman now in her 50s who alleges that Cosby plied her with alcohol and molested her in 1974 at the Playboy Mansion when she was aged 15.Existing California law generally limits prosecution of a felony sexual offense to 10 years after the offense is committed.

column1: Only two in 100 rapists will be convicted of a felony and spend any time in prison
column2: according to the U.S. Department of Justice. ""Governor Jerry Brown's signature of SB 813 tells every rape and sexual assault victim in California that they matter and that
column3: regardless of when they are ready to come forward
column4: they will always have an opportunity to seek justice in a court of law
column5: said bill author Senator Connie Leyva.

column1: Rapists should never be able to evade legal consequences simply because an arbitrary time limit has expired
column2: she said.The bill will not work retroactively and will not help some of Cosby's accusers
column3: according to Gloria Allred
column4: an attorney who represents several of the comedian's alleged victims.

column1: The governors of Nevada and Colorado have signed similar bills extending the statute of limitations to 20 years  for rape cases into law. The California law takes effect on Jan. 1
column2: 2017. (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein; Additional reporting by Rory Carroll; Editing by David Gregorio and Sandra Maler)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-jersey-bridgegate-idUSKCN11Y344	'Bridgegate' witness casts more doubt on NJ Governor Christie's denials	"
By Joseph Ax
| NEWARK
column2: N.J.

column1: NEWARK
column2: N.J. In December 2013
column3: as the ""Bridgegate"" scandal was unraveling
column4: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie's chief spokesman learned the truth: that lanes had been closed at the George Washington Bridge to punish a local mayor for political reasons.That was the testimony from former Port Authority of New York and New Jersey executive David Wildstein on Wednesday
column5: who told jurors in Newark federal court he informed Christie's press secretary Michael Drewniak that he executed the scheme with the approval of Christie aides.Wildstein has said several key figures in Christie's inner circle knew about the plot as it was occurring or soon afterward - including Christie himself
column6: who was told of the closures by Wildstein as they unfolded in September 2013
column7: according to Wildstein's testimony on Tuesday.Christie
column8: who is not accused of wrongdoing
column9: has repeatedly denied any knowledge of the plot at the time
column10: but Wildstein's testimony has bolstered the government's assertion the governor knew about the scandal earlier than he has acknowledged. The scandal helped derail Christie's bid for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination and could endanger his best chance at a political future: a role in Donald Trump's administration should the Republican presidential candidate win a Nov. 8 election.

column1: The governor's former deputy chief of staff
column2: Bridget Kelly
column3: and a former Port Authority executive
column4: Bill Baroni
column5: are charged with deliberately creating gridlock in Fort Lee
column7: after the town's mayor declined to endorse Christie's 2013 re-election bid.Wildstein said on Wednesday he met with Drewniak on Dec. 4 and offered to resign.""I told him the stories were out of control

column1: Drewniak has previously confirmed that Wildstein told him of the closures
column2: but has denied knowing it was political payback.Wildstein also said he met with Christie's chief counsel
column3: Charlie McKenna
column4: two days later and told him about the scheme
column5: though he did not say whether he disclosed the motivation for the plot.Wildstein previously said he informed Michael DuHaime
column7: in November. He has also testified that Christie's campaign manager
column9: the chairman of the Port Authority; and a board member
column11: were aware of the plot beforehand.

column1: Stepien's lawyer has said he had no role in the scheme
column2: while Samson and Schuber have denied advance knowledge.Defense lawyers began questioning Wildstein on Wednesday and sought to portray him as the true mastermind of the scheme
column3: even though Baroni was nominally his superior.Michael Baldassare
column4: a lawyer for Baroni
column5: also suggested Wildstein's testimony was biased because he is seeking a reduced sentence after pleading guilty to two counts of conspiracy. (Reporting by Joseph Ax; Editing by Scott Malone and Alan Crosby)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-hampshire-election-selfies-idUSKCN11Y2WT	New Hampshire 'ballot selfie' ban unconstitutional: appeals court	"
By Scott Malone
| BOSTON
BOSTON A 2014 New Hampshire law prohibiting voters from taking selfies with their ballots on election day is an unconstitutional infringement on the right to free speech
column2: a federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday.The New England state had banned the practice
column3: which has become a popular way for voters to show support for favored candidates
column4: claiming that it would set the stage for a return of the vote-buying scandals that rocked many U.S. states in the 19th century.Three New Hampshire citizens
column5: including a man who wrote in the name of his dog to express dismay at his choices in the 2014 Republican primary for the U.S. Senate
column6: sued the state that year claiming the measure violated their rights to free expression
column7: as protected by the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution.A federal court in New Hampshire sided with them
column9: making its case in Boston just two weeks ago. The appeals court swiftly rejected its arguments.

column1: The statute's purposes cannot justify the restrictions it imposes on speech
column2: Circuit Judge Sandra Lynch wrote in the court's decision.New Hampshire's argument that ballot selfies could lead to people selling their votes or being compelled by their employers to vote in a certain way fell short in no small part because the state had no evidence of that actually happening
column3: Lynch wrote.

column1: The legislative history of the bill does not contain any corroborated evidence of vote buying or voter coercion in New Hampshire during the 20th and 21st centuries
column2: she wrote. ""Digital photography
column3: the internet
column4: and social media are not unknown quantities -- they have been ubiquitous for several election cycles
column5: without being shown to have the effect of furthering vote buying or voter intimidation.""Lynch also noted that several federal and state laws in effect in New Hampshire already make it illegal to buy or sell a vote
column6: which would allow prosecutors to take on allegations of election tampering even in an environment where selfies were permitted.

column1: Other states
column2: including nearby Rhode Island
column3: have passed laws explicitly allowing ballot selfies
column4: partly reasoning that the trend has helped younger voters show their enthusiasm for the democratic process. (Reporting by Scott Malone; Editing by Tom Brown)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-detroit-education-idUSKCN11Y2UC	Michigan Attorney General says weak Detroit schools can be closed	"
By Timothy Mclaughlin
| CHICAGO
CHICAGO Underperforming schools in the cash-strapped city of Detroit can be closed this school year
column2: Michigan's Attorney General said in a legal opinion issued Wednesday to clarify an existing state law. The position is the latest development in a battle between the state's Republican and Democratic lawmakers over how best to address Detroit's struggling school system.   Attorney General Bill Schuette
column3: a Republican
column4: said schools operated by the Detroit Public School Community District that are among the lowest achieving 5 percent of all public schools during the three preceding school years can be shuttered by the state's School Reform Officer (SRO).Republican Governor Rick Snyder
column5: who in June approved a dramatic restructuring of Detroit's school system
column6: previously accepted the opinion of an outside law firm that the SRO could not close schools until 2019
column7: according to the Detroit Free Press.  ""The law is clear: Michigan parents and their children do not have to be stuck indefinitely in a failing school
column8: Schuette said in a statement on Wednesday. ""Detroit students and parents deserve accountability and high performing schools. If a child can't spell opportunity

column1: Some Democrats argue that the newly restructured school district needs additional time to re-evaluate the performance of schools and integrate best learning practices. Schuette's opinion said the SRO could issue a mandatory notice of closure to a school
column2: which would then determine the best time to close before the end of the current school term.  If a school is closed
column3: students will be re-assigned to another school.

column1: The Detroit public school system
column2: which has nearly 46
column3: 000 students
column4: has been under state control since 2009 because of a financial emergency. Of the 124 worst-performing schools in the state
column5: 47 are Detroit public schools
column6: according to a list released by the SRO earlier this month. The recent restructuring of the school system splits it into two distinct parts in an effort to improve the academically and financially struggling system.

column1: Ari Adler
column2: a spokesman for Snyder's office
column3: said on Wednesday that the governor's office was reviewing Schuette's legal opinion. Republican House Speaker Kevin Cotter
column4: who asked for a clarification of the law from Schuette welcomed the decision on Wednesday. ""Detroit students need a final decision
column5: and this opinion provides one
column6: Cotter said in a statement. State Representative Sherry Gay-Dagnogo
column9: describing the attorney general as ""totally out of touch with the needs of our community.""  (Editing by Andrew Hay)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-illinois-idUSKCN11Y2TM	Illinois attorney general appeals bar on Election Day voter registration	"
CHICAGO The Illinois Attorney General has appealed a federal judge ruling that blocks same-day registration at polling places in the state's most populous counties
column2: a spokeswoman for the office said on Wednesday. The appeal submitted by the state's Attorney General
column3: Lisa Madigan
column4: to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 7th Circuit
column5: seeks to reverse a ruling that bars Election Day voter registration at polling places in counties with populations of 100
column6: 000 or more. Such registrations were allowed under a state law enacted last year.The appeal was filed on Tuesday evening
column7: according to court documents and Maura Possley
column8: a spokeswoman for the Attorney General's Office. The ruling
column9: issued Tuesday by Judge Samuel Der-Yeghiayan of the Northern District of Illinois
column10: resulted from a federal court lawsuit brought in August against the state law by a group aligned with a conservative think tank and came six weeks before the Nov. 8 election.[nL2N1C321W]

column1: The Chicago-based Liberty Justice Center
column2: which filed the lawsuit
column3: argued that the population threshold unconstitutionally discriminated against voters in less populated counties and boosted Democrats in heavily Democratic Cook County
column4: where Chicago is located.In his ruling
column5: Der-Yeghiayan wrote that the law provided an advantage to urban voters over their rural counterparts.

column1: The law
column2: passed in late 2014 by the Democratic-led legislature and signed into law in early 2015 by former Democratic Governor Pat Quinn
column3: allowed Election Day voter registration for the first time
column4: including at polling places.

column1: But the section of the law regarding polling place registration pertained only to counties with populations of 100
column2: 000 or more. (Reporting by Timothy Mclaughlin; Editing by Frances Kerry)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-sept11-saudi-whitehouse-idUSKCN11Y2KV	White House calls Senate override of veto of September 11 bill 'embarrassing'	"
ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE The White House on Wednesday slammed the Senate's nearly unanimous vote to reject President Barack Obama's veto of legislation allowing relatives of the victims of the Sept. 11
column3: attacks to sue Saudi Arabia's government.""This is the single most embarrassing thing this United States' Senate has done possibly since 1983
column4: White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters in a briefing
column5: referring to the last time when the chamber so overwhelmingly overrode a president's veto. Earnest said some lawmakers had only recently been informed about potential drawbacks to approving the legislation.

column1: For those senators to then move forward in overriding the president's veto that would prevent those negative consequences is an abdication of their basic responsibilities as elected representatives of the American people
column2: he said.

column1: (Reporting by Roberta Rampton
column2: editing by G Crosse)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN11Y2EW	Trump tries to soothe Polish-Americans' concerns about his NATO stance	"
By Steve Holland
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Wednesday sought to allay the concerns of Polish-Americans who questioned him about his commitment to Poland given his tough stance on NATO and talk of working with Russian President Vladimir Putin.Trump
column2: at a small roundtable meeting with Polish-American leaders
column3: heard their concerns about his demand that NATO nations bear more of the financial burden of their defense and his words of praise for Putin.""As president I will honor Poland's sacrifices for freedom. We're committed to a strong Poland
column4: very committed
column5: totally committed
column6: and a strong Eastern Europe as a bulwark for freedom and security
column7: Trump said.Trump has rattled NATO allies and many U.S. national security experts by saying that if elected on Nov. 8
column8: he would demand that NATO members pay up their defense contributions of 2 percent of GDP or else have to pay for their own security.

column1: Many nations in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have lagged in their defense spending
column2: to the frustration of U.S. leaders
column3: but there has never been a move to cut them out of the U.S. security umbrella because of this.In Chicago
column4: Trump hailed Poland as being up to date with its defense contributions.

column1: We want NATO to be strong which means we want more nations to follow the example of Poland
column2: Trump said. ""If all made the same contributions as Poland
column3: all our allies would be more secure.""There are an estimated 9.5 million Americans of Polish descent in the United States
column4: many of them clustered in Midwestern states that may play an important role in deciding who wins the election.

column1: Tim Kuzma
column2: president of a group called the Polish Falcons of America
column3: told Reuters that during the small roundtable event Trump was asked about whether he would be a strong friend to Poland.The message to Trump was ""Would a Trump administration support Poland?"" Kuzma said. ""Would a Trump administration honor the commitments to NATO? And he was very affirmative that he would and that he believes in a strong NATO."" (Reporting By Steve Holland; Editing by Frances Kerry)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-maine-lepage-idUSKCN11Y1MT	Washington Post calls for Maine governor to resign	"
BOSTON The Washington Post on Wednesday called on Maine Governor Paul LePage to resign
column2: following a series of incidents in which the two-term Republican made racially charged statements and threatened a Democratic lawmaker in an obscenity-laden email.LePage
column3: whose term extends through 2018
column4: last month lashed out at a state lawmaker who criticized his comments blaming black and Hispanic people from out of state for the heroin trade in Maine.In an editorial titled ""Maine's unhinged governor
column5: the newspaper wrote ""LePage threatens to remake his state's image from a vacation paradise of surreal natural beauty to a hotbed of hatred.""LePage had told reporters he had collected a three-ring binder of people arrested for trafficking drugs in the state and that 90 percent of those in it were black or Hispanic. The governor released the binder this week and a review by local media found that closer to one in three arrestees in it matched LePage's description.

column1: Maine legislative leaders last month briefly considered convening a special session to reprimand LePage for the outburst
column2: but the effort collapsed with the two parties unable to agree on whether they wanted to censure him or pursue impeachment.A spokeswoman for the governor dismissed the editorial as biased.

column1: The Post did not contact anyone from the governor's office to fact-check this biased piece of propaganda
column2: spokeswoman Adrienne Bennett said in an email. ""Clearly
column3: the Post editorial board is exempt from reporting facts.""Asked about what factual inaccuracies in the editorial concerned the governor
column4: Bennett challenged the Post's description of LePage declining to attend a 2011 Martin Luther King Jr. Day event hosted by the state's NAACP chapter
column5: noting that he had instead attended a Rotary Club event honoring the slain civil rights activist.

column1: At the time that he declined the NAACP's invitation
column2: in his first month as governor
column3: LePage said that critics of his decision could ""kiss my butt."" (Reporting by Scott Malone; Editing by Meredith Mazzilli and Lisa Shumaker)"
